etymology.description: 武 (martial; military) + 林 (forest; multitude) = the martial-arts community ('martial forest').
etymology.interpretation: Refers to the circles/world of martial artists, schools, and their affairs, especially in wuxia culture. Using 林 evokes a dense multitude of sects and figures.

examples.chinese: 他被尊为武林高手(他被尊為武林高手)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bèi zūn wéi wǔlín gāoshǒu.
examples.english: He is respected as a top expert in the martial-arts world.

examples.chinese: 各大门派齐聚少林参加武林大会(各大門派齊聚少林參加武林大會)。
examples.pinyin: Gè dà ménpài qíjù Shàolín cānjiā wǔlín dàhuì.
examples.english: Major sects gathered at Shaolin to attend the martial-arts assembly.

examples.chinese: 在江湖中，武林讲究侠义和规矩(在江湖中，武林講究俠義和規矩)。
examples.pinyin: Zài jiānghú zhōng, wǔlín jiǎngjiu xiáyì hé guījǔ.
examples.english: In the jianghu, the martial world values chivalry and rules.
